title: How to Cut a Shirt

steps.headline: Cut a slit into the shirt on either side of the collar using some sharp fabric scissors.
steps.description: Cut the slit along the collar seam to serve as a visual guide for the rest of your cutting project.

steps.headline: Use fabric scissors to cut the collar off of the shirt.
Grab the fabric at the shoulder seam and pull it.
steps.description: Doing this will make the neckline curl over.

steps.headline: Wear the shirt over a tank top or a camisole.

methods.name: Cut a Shirt to Bare Your Midriff

steps.headline: Get your shirt.
Put on the shirt that you want to cut.
Measure the distance from the shoulder seam to just past your waistline using a vinyl tape measure.
steps.description: You want to leave just a little extra fabric so the shirt will roll up at your waistline and not high above it.

steps.headline: Mark the measurement on your shirt using a fabric marker or a piece of chalk.
Cut the shirt straight across using sharp fabric scissors.
steps.description: It's easiest if you place the shirt on a flat surface.

steps.headline: Pull the edges of the shirt so that the fabric will curl over.
Finished!

methods.name: Cut a Shirt to Create a Tank Top or Muscle Top

steps.headline: Cut off the sleeves.
steps.description: Start about 1" (2.5 cm) below the armpit and cut all the way up to the neckline. Don't discard your scrap fabric.

steps.headline: Trim off the neckline if you wish.
steps.description: Cut at the seam so that you don't create a one-shoulder effect.

steps.headline: Pull the edges, so they curl over nicely.
steps.description: Optional: Lay the shirt face down on a flat surface. Pinch the fabric together at the base of the armpits. Optional: Wrap your fabric scraps around the pinched area. Tie a knot to secure the fabric and tuck the knot underneath the wrap.

steps.headline: Wear the shirt on its own.
steps.description: If it reveals too much skin, then wear a bandeau or a tank underneath it.

methods.name: Cut a Shirt with a Razor

steps.headline: Choose a tight-fitting t-shirt for the best effect.
Select the area of your body that you want to expose.
steps.description: You can place razor slits across the back of your shirt, for instance.

steps.headline: Lay your shirt on a flat surface.
steps.description: Place a cutting board between the front and back of your shirt so that you don't cut through both layers.

steps.headline: Cut parallel horizontal lines in your shirt using a razor blade or a utility knife.
steps.description: You can cut lines of equal length, or you can cut a long line at the top and cut continuously shorter lines in sequence for a triangular effect.

steps.headline: Finished!
steps.description: Optional: Wash the shirt. The sections that you cut will roll up at the edges to create a punk-ish effect.

methods.name: Cut a Shirt to Create Tied Sleeves

steps.headline: Cut the hem off of both your T-shirt sleeves using sharp fabric scissors.
Use fabric scissors to cut a slit in the sleeves from the bottom to the shoulder seam.
Pull the edges, so they curl over.
steps.description: This will also give you more slack to for tying in the next step.

steps.headline: Tie the loose edges of the fabric together at the base of the slit.
steps.description: This tie will create a cute peep-through effect.

steps.headline: Done!
steps.description: Wear your top with its cute new sleeves.
